metadata./Title: Tracheal stenosis misdiagnosed as asthma: a case report

sections.Introduction: Introduction Tracheal stenosis is a known complication following intubation. However, owing to its delayed presentation and symptoms of progressive wheezing and respiratory difficulty, it is often misdiagnosed as asthma.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We present the case of a 10-year-old Asian boy who presented with cough, wheezing, and dysp nea. He was misdiagnosed with severe, uncontrolled asthma and respiratory failure, remaining unresponsive to initial 
asthma management. During his current admission, he had difficult intubation, necessitating an emergency tracheostomy. Further subsequent examination revealed grade III tracheal stenosis.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion This case highlights the importance of considering tracheal stenosis as a differential diagnosis in children 
presenting with dyspnea, cough, and wheezing, particularly if there is a history of prior intubation. The airway should 
be secured immediately in a controlled environment by an otolaryngologist or anesthetist.
Keywords  Subglottic stenosis, Tracheal stenosis, Asthma, Tracheostomy
Introduction
Tracheal stenosis has various etiologies, including 
trauma from surgery, intubation, accidents, inhalation 
injuries, or inflammatory diseases such as Wegener’s 
granulomatosis, sarcoidosis, or systemic lupus erythema tosus [1]. However, the vast majority of cases result from 
prolonged intubation or tracheostomy [2]. Even when 
high-volume, low-pressure cuffed tubes are used, airway 
stenosis can occur in up to 11% of intubated or trache ostomy patients, even after less than 24  h of intubation 
[3]. When tracheal stenosis occurs, it is often difficult 
to diagnose and manage. The common presentation of 
tracheal stenosis includes general respiratory symptoms 
of wheezing, dyspnea, exercise intolerance, stridor, or cough. In children, an otherwise mild respiratory infec tion can lead to increased work of breathing. If a dysp neic patient has a history of intubation or tracheostomy, 
tracheal stenosis should be considered [4]. These symp toms may not initially suggest an airway stenosis and may 
be misdiagnosed as asthma, a far more common condi tion, especially in pediatric population. By the time the 
child becomes symptomatic, the tracheal stenosis usually 
progresses to involve 30–50% of the lumen diameter.
Case presentation
We present the case of a 10-year-old Asian boy, weight 
41 kg, with known history of adrenal insufficiency but no 
prior documented history of asthma, who presented in the 
emergency department with complaints of cough, wheez ing, and increased work of breathing for 1 day. Ten months 
prior, he had been admitted with adrenal crisis and shock, 
requiring intubation for 3 days. He was successfully extu bated without complications and discharged home. How ever, he had multiple visits to the emergency department Open Access

in the months following his intubation, presenting with 
cough, wheezing, and increased work of breathing. He was 
treated presumptively as a case of acute severe asthma due 
to bilateral expiratory wheezing and respiratory distress. 
No other respiratory diagnoses were previously docu mented, and he showed partial but temporary responses to 
asthma treatments during these visits.
During this visit, he presented with similar symptoms, 
including increased work of breathing requiring pediatric 
intensive care unit (PICU) admission, as his condition did 
not respond to initial management. On examination, he 
was tachypneic with harsh vesicular breathing and bilat eral wheeze on auscultation. Laboratory testing revealed 
leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14.4k/L and 
a left shift. The differential showed 89% neutrophils and 
6.3% lymphocytes. Hemoglobin was 11.3  g/dL, platelets 
were 327k/L, and arterial blood gas analysis showed pH 
of 7.42, partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 32.9 mmHg, 
partial pressure of oxygen of 75  mmHg, bicarbonate of 
20.90  meq/L, and base excess of −2.8  meq/L. Although 
the patient’s chest X-ray did not show typical signs of 
hyperinflation, asthma was presumed based on the clini cal presentation of bilateral wheezing, increased work of 
breathing, and a history of multiple similar episodes that 
responded to bronchodilator therapy.
He was managed for acute severe asthma with inhaled 
beta agonists and anticholinergic, systemic steroids, 
and magnesium sulfate followed by terbutaline infu sion, along with trial of noninvasive bilevel positive 
pressure ventilation through face mask. However, his 
symptoms remained refractory, and he progressed to 
hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation. Rapid 
sequence intubation was attempted using a video laryn goscope, but we were unable to pass the endotracheal 
tube beyond the vocal cords. Initially, an age-appropri ate uncuffed endotracheal tube was used, followed by 
multiple attempts with smaller sized tubes, all of which 
were unsuccessful. A size 2.5 laryngeal mask airway was 
inserted, and bag and mask ventilation was provided. The 
child was rushed to the operating room (OR), where an 
emergent tracheostomy was done, and through this, we 
were able to manage airway adequately.
Subsequent bedside bronchoscopy revealed grade III 
tracheal stenosis (Fig.  1). He was weaned off mechani cal ventilation successfully, with no further asthma 
treatment, and the tracheostomy remained in place. 
The patient was later discharged with a follow-up plan 
for open resection and anastomosis or laser treatment 
3–4  weeks post discharge. Carbon dioxide laser exci sion of subglottic stenosis was performed after 3 weeks, 
and the patient was successfully decannulated from the 
tracheostomy tube. His postprocedure course remained 
uneventful, and he was discharged on oral medications.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Acquired tracheal stenosis is frequently misdiagnosed 
as an acute exacerbation of asthma in the clinical set ting [5]. This case stands out owing to the combination 
of severe tracheal stenosis (grade III) and the recurrent 
misdiagnosis of asthma over an extended period, even 
in the absence of typical signs such as hyperinflation on 
chest X-ray. The patient had multiple emergency vis its before the correct diagnosis was made, underscoring 
how tracheal stenosis can persist undiagnosed in chil dren, especially when there is a history of past intubation 
and no prior asthma diagnosis. The delay in diagnosis in 
this case, despite persistent symptoms, emphasizes the 
importance of considering alternative diagnoses early in 
the evaluation of children with refractory wheezing, par ticularly when the clinical response to asthma therapy is 
inadequate.
While the subglottis is not typically the narrowest part 
of the airway in a 10-year-old, subglottic stenosis can 
still occur owing to factors such as prolonged intubation, 
which the patient experienced for 3  days. Injury can be 
caused by infection or mechanical trauma, usually from 
endotracheal intubation, but it can also result from blunt, 
penetrating, or other trauma. Factors implicated in the 
development of subglottic stenosis related to endotra cheal intubation include the size of the endotracheal tube 
relative to the child’s larynx, the duration of intubation, 
motion of the endotracheal tube while the child is intu bated, and multiple extubation failures requiring reintu bations. Sex hormones have been implicated as a possible 
cause owing to the female preponderance afflicted with 
this condition, but several reports were not able to con firm the presence of estrogen receptors in biopsies [6].
A study by Schweiger et al. indicated that children who 
were intubated and inadequately sedated had a higher 
risk of developing subglottic stenosis. The study, which 
included children aged 30  days to 5  years who under went endotracheal intubation, found that the incidence 
of undersedation was significantly higher in those who 
developed subglottic stenosis compared with those who 
did not (15.8% versus 3.65%) [7].

Tracheal stenosis grading is based on the percentage 
of airway narrowing. Grade I involves less than 50% nar rowing, grade II is 51–70% narrowing, grade III repre sents 71–99% narrowing, and grade IV refers to complete 
obstruction of the airway. In our case, the patient’s grade 
III stenosis indicates severe narrowing of 71–99%, which 
significantly impacted airway management and required 
urgent tracheostomy.
Flow-volume loops (FVL) remain the most effective 
method for detecting upper airway obstruction (UAO), 
even before symptoms develops [8]. A flow-volume loop 
could have been beneficial in differentiating between 
intrathoracic obstruction, such as asthma, and extratho racic obstruction, such as subglottic stenosis, particularly 
while the patient was on noninvasive bilevel positive air way pressure (NIV BiPAP) support.
In this case, the decision to perform a tracheostomy 
was critical, as it effectively bypassed the subglottic ste nosis and secured the airway. However, if the stenosis 
had been located distal to the subglottis, a tracheostomy 
might not have adequately addressed the airway obstruc tion. Bronchoscopy was performed to assess the extent 
of the tracheal stenosis following the patient’s emergency 
tracheostomy. This procedure allowed for direct visu alization of the stenosis, providing critical information 
about the location and severity of the airway blockage. 
If the stenosis had been too severe to evaluate via bron choscopy, a computed tomography (CT) scan could have 
been used as an alternative to help identify the narrow ing. A thorough endoscopic evaluation in the operating 
room is essential to guide further management and treat ment planning [9].
Treatment via an endoscopic or open surgical approach 
is dependent on the patient’s symptoms, the site of 
involvement, and the degree of stenosis. The ideal treat ment plan must be individualized and balanced between 
a more definitive but invasive surgical resection with 
end-to-end anastomosis or more conservative endo scopic treatments, which have a greater risk of recur rence [10]. Useful algorithms for treatment selection are 
now available, using features of the case including the 
length of the stenosis, lumen diameter, cartilage involve ment, and prior treatment attempts.
Conclusion
Tracheal stenosis can be easily misdiagnosed as asthma, 
particularly for inpatients with history of intubation. When 
a patient presents with signs and symptoms of respira tory distress, tracheal stenosis should be considered in the 
differential diagnosis and the airway should be secured 
promptly in a secure environment by an anesthesia/
otolaryngologist.Acknowledgements
